Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Experimental Evolution of Mating System under Varying Pollinator Availability in Mimulus guttatus
Award.AbstractNarration:
The evolution of plant mating systems has been a topic of great interest throughout the history of evolutionary biology. Despite the extensive description of mating system variation, a great deal remains unknown about the specific mechanisms involved in mating system transitions. The proposed studies will provide a comprehensive quantification of the most immediate evolutionary changes in the transition from outcrossing to self-fertilization using Mimulus guttatus, the yellow monkeyflower, as a model system. The first objective explores phenotypic and genetic changes over time in populations experiencing opposing pollinator regimes: abundant bumblebee (Bombus) pollinators vs. no pollinators. This transition has never before been observed directly in the laboratory using experimental evolution. The second objective will investigate the mechanistic relationship between Bombus and Mimulus; identifying specific selective pressures in bee-pollinated populations such as the contribution of pollinator preference to natural selection.

These studies will examine the mechanistic evolution of self-fertilization under pollinator limitation, vitally important in today?s changing world as human activities alter plant-pollinator interactions through landscape modification and climate change. In addition, during the course of the project undergraduate students will receive specialized training and mentorship in project experimental design, data collection, analysis, and dissemination of results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Experimental evolution of mating system under varying pollinator availability in Mimulus guttatus. 

 

Flowering plants cannot move around, and as a consequence, have evolved a diversity of reproductive strategies. Sexual reproduction occurs either when pollen is transferred from one plant to another (outcrossing), or when pollen from one flower fertilizes ovaries of the same plant (self-fertilization or selfing). Both strategies can occur either with or without the aid of pollinators, but many flowering plants have evolved mutualistic relationships with pollinators to facilitate outcrossing.

 

Unfortunately, plants that rely on pollinators for reproduction are currently experiencing increasing environmental changes caused by humans. Recent events, including habitat loss, climate change, invasive species introductions, and novel disease—such as honeybee colony collapse disorder— shift the abundance and composition of the available pollinator pool, disrupting plant reproduction. These pollinator declines affect not only wild plants, but also crop plants heavily relied upon worldwide, such as many fruits, nuts, vegetables, spices, and oilseeds. Theory suggests that some plants may respond to a loss of pollinators by changing their reproductive strategies from pollinator-reliant outcrossing to abiotic self-fertilization. This study examined the evolutionary response of a western North American wildflower, Mimulus guttatus, to an experimental loss of pollinators, documenting both phenotypic and genetic changes occurring during a real-time transition from outcrossing to selfing.

 

We used experimental evolution to document the immediate effects of pollinator loss in a plant that typically outcrosses. Initially equivalent populations evolved for 9 generations within two pollination treatments: abundant bumblebee (Bombus) pollinators vs. a complete lack of pollinators. We recorded plant phenotypes and genotypes at two time steps, phase one and two, after 5 and 9 generations of pollination treatments, respectively. We observed rapid evolution in phase one. Populations without pollinators (No Bee) displayed reduced fitness in the early generations of the study but then rebounded, culminating in a ten-fold increase in self-fertilization capacity compared to the initial ancestral population (Figure 1). Two measured traits, herkogamy and selfing seed, showed clear association with pollination treatment. Herkogamy is a measurement of the physical distance between the male and female reproductive parts. Reduced herkogamy was correlated with increased selfing ability in our study (Figure 2) and is frequently found in wild selfing species.

 

In the second phase of the study (generations 6-9), evolution continued in some traits, but not others. The floral shape character, tube length, increased in the No Bee populations, mimicking the lengthened floral morphology of a related self-fertilizing species, M. nasutus. Despite the rapid increase in selfed fitness of the No Bee populations in the initial phase of the experiment, no continued increase in selfing capacity occurred in the final four generations. Genotyping of our experimental plants showed rapid allele frequency changes occurring in the No Bee populations that correlated with the evolving phenotypes.

 

The patterns of phenotypic and genetic changes we observed in the 9 generations of the study favor a sequential model for the evolution of self-fertilization; traits immediately essential to continued survival and reproduction evolve first (e.g. herkogamy and self seed production) and are then followed by others (e.g. flower shape).
